newsitem.title: ISRAEL: Israeli shares end higher on inflation hopes.
newsitem.headline: Israeli shares end higher on inflation hopes.

text.p: Israeli shares closed higher on Sunday in thin trading on continued hopes for slower inflation and lower interest rates, traders said.

The benchmark Mishtanim index of the top 100 shares rose 0.27 percent, or 0.53 points, to 199.45 on a low all-share turnover of 55 million shekels against 93 million shekels on Thursday, the last day of trading before the Israeli weekend.
The Maof 25 blue chip index gained 0.20 percent to 209.37.
"The market rose because investors are predicting that in the long run the Bank of Israel will have to lower interest rates because the inflation is declining," said Amir Eayal at Epsilon Securities.
But, he added: "The rise of the market is meaningless because of the low volume. This is not a real market."
Last week, the central bank announced it was holding interest rates for December at 15.2 percent.

Other traders were more positive about the market's condition. "The market continues to show strength," said Danniele Finn, head of sales at Batucha Securities and Investment. "The mood is very positive and the technical indicators are positive. Activity was relatively low today because foreign investors were not active."

She noted that the market moved higher due to speculative activity in Maof contracts on Thursday, the expiry for the November contract. "Investors expected the market to decline today because of profit-taking, yet the market continued rising today," Finn said.
Bezeq Israel Telecom declined 0.75 percent to 785 after reporting a decline in third-quarter net profit to 149 million shekels from 163.7 million a year earlier.

All three successor companies to Elbit reported third-quarter earnings on Sunday and continued to traded with volatility. The three began trading separately on the Tel Aviv Stock Exchange on Thursday.

Elbit Ltd was the most active share of the day and plunged 18.0 percent to 2,627 on volume of 3.1 million shekels. It reported a third-quarter net loss of $1.95 million shekels against net loss of $4.3 million a year earlier.

Elbit Systems, the third most active share, surged 5.25 percent to 2,387 on turnover of 2.7 million shekels The company reported a third-quarter net profit of $3.8 million, down from $6.3 million at the same period last year.
Elbit Medical Imaging fell 2.25 percent to 1,226. It reported a third-quarter net profit of $1.7 million against $1.3 million a year earlier.
Elite Industries gained 0.25 percent to 1,469 after reporting a third-quarter net profit of 8.7 million shekels, down from 14.3 million shekels a year earlier.
The First International Bank of Israel tumbled 5.0 percent to 35,015, which traders said was due to profit- taking after it rose sharply on Thursday on the back of options speculation.
Teva Pharmaceutical Industries, the second most active share, gained 0.25 percent to 149,628 on turnover of 2.9 million shekels.
